title: Maleficent 2: Angelina Jolie queen of sass as she battles Michelle Pfeiffer
text:
Angelina Jolie is the queen of sass in Maleficent Mistress of Evil (Picture: Disney / Getty)

Maleficent: Mistress Of Evil has shown us to never judge a book by its cover, as Angelina Jolie might have been the queen of sass, but she has sure stolen our hearts once again in the stunning sequel.

Norwegian film director Joachim Rønning is at the helm of the fantasy epic, and has done an incredible job of creating a new universe that was plainly beautiful to look at.

From fairies to tree men, adorable doe-eyed hedgehogs to fairy godmothers, the make-believe world looked like something out of a children’s fairy-tale book, instantly making us fall in love with the creation.

And then there was Ange.

Draped in black with prosthetic cheekbones, the 44-year-old had us fixated to the screen with her CGI’d wings and hilarious one-liners (that both children and their parents will enjoy).

Despite embodying the villain, the actress made sure family and love was at the heart of the movie through her onscreen relationship with Elle Fanning, who plays Maleficent’s daughter, Princess Aurora.

She embodied the villain Maleficent (Picture: Disney)

Elle Fanning made sure love was instilled throughout (Picture: Disney)

The duo brought to life their challenged mother and daughter relationship, as they battled against evil together, seeing them fall out of love but regain trust as the film went on.

Elle is the perfect choice to play a Disney princess, with her innocent look yet strong character – it’s as though the movie was a lesson to young girls that you don’t always have to be a damsel in distress, and can be the hero to your own story.

It was refreshing to see such a long list of leading actresses, with Michelle Pfeiffer starring alongside Angelina as Queen Ingrith.

The 61-year-old’s character found herself embroiled in a maternal war with the Mistress of Evil, as they fought over Aurora and her wedding to Prince Phillip (Harris Dickinson).

And while the Queen was dressed in white, and battling the ‘dark fae’ who had been oppressed because of their race, it turns out she was, in fact, the true antagonist.

We wish Ange had more scenes with Michelle Pfeiffer (Picture: Getty)

The story arc appeared to reflect today’s society with the constant, and unnecessary, fear of the unknown being instilled into the community by those in power.

But as Disney always assures, (spoiler alert!) love won the battle – which is something the real world is yet to see.

While Michelle and Ange stole the show with their quips and charm, we would have liked to have seen the pair have more onscreen time together.

Their chemistry was incredible and had us whipping out the popcorn while we watched the drama between the two characters unfold.

It was a movie full of life lessons transformed by fantastical elements that will hopefully be firmly embedded for the next generation.

Maleficent: Mistress of Evil is in UK cinemas 18 October.
